trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database security guidelines and limitations
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database security guidelines and limitations

trans-unit.source: This topic describes the Microsoft Azure SQL Database guidelines and limitations related to security.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes the Microsoft Azure SQL Database guidelines and limitations related to security.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following points when managing the security of your Azure SQL Databases.
trans-unit.target: Consider the following points when managing the security of your Azure SQL Databases.

trans-unit.source: Firewall
trans-unit.target: Firewall

trans-unit.source: The Azure SQL Database service is only available through TCP port 1433.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SQL Database service is only available through TCP port 1433.

trans-unit.source: To access a SQL Database from your computer, ensure that your firewall allows outgoing TCP communication on TCP port 1433.
trans-unit.target: To access a SQL Database from your computer, ensure that your firewall allows outgoing TCP communication on TCP port 1433.

trans-unit.source: As part of the connection process, connections from Azure virtual machines are redirected to a different IP address and port, unique for each worker role.
trans-unit.target: As part of the connection process, connections from Azure virtual machines are redirected to a different IP address and port, unique for each worker role.

trans-unit.source: The port number will be in the range from 11000 to 11999.
trans-unit.target: The port number will be in the range from 11000 to 11999.

trans-unit.source: Before you can connect to the Azure SQL Database server for the first time, you must use the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com) or [Azure Platform Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/microsoft.onmicrosoft.com#Workspaces/All/dashboard) to configure the Azure SQL Database firewall.
trans-unit.target: Before you can connect to the Azure SQL Database server for the first time, you must use the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com) or [Azure Platform Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/microsoft.onmicrosoft.com#Workspaces/All/dashboard) to configure the Azure SQL Database firewall.

trans-unit.source: You will need to create a server-level firewall setting that enables connection attempts from your computer or Azure to Azure SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: You will need to create a server-level firewall setting that enables connection attempts from your computer or Azure to Azure SQL Database server.

trans-unit.source: Further, if you want to control access to certain databases in your Azure SQL Database server, create database-level firewall rules for the respective databases.
trans-unit.target: Further, if you want to control access to certain databases in your Azure SQL Database server, create database-level firewall rules for the respective databases.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure SQL Database firewall](sql-database-firewall-configure.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure SQL Database firewall](sql-database-firewall-configure.md).

trans-unit.source: Connection encryption and certificate validation
trans-unit.target: Connection encryption and certificate validation

trans-unit.source: All communications between SQL Database and your application require encryption (SSL) at all times.
trans-unit.target: All communications between SQL Database and your application require encryption (SSL) at all times.

trans-unit.source: If your client application does not validate certificates upon connection, your connection to SQL Database is susceptible to "man in the middle" attacks.
trans-unit.target: If your client application does not validate certificates upon connection, your connection to SQL Database is susceptible to "man in the middle" attacks.

trans-unit.source: To validate certificates with application code or tools, explicitly request an encrypted connection and do not trust the server certificates.
trans-unit.target: To validate certificates with application code or tools, explicitly request an encrypted connection and do not trust the server certificates.

trans-unit.source: If your application code or tools do not request an encrypted connection, they will still receive encrypted connections.
trans-unit.target: If your application code or tools do not request an encrypted connection, they will still receive encrypted connections.

trans-unit.source: However, they may not validate the server certificates and thus will be susceptible to "man in the middle" attacks.
trans-unit.target: However, they may not validate the server certificates and thus will be susceptible to "man in the middle" attacks.

trans-unit.source: To validate certificates with ADO.NET application code, set ``Encrypt=True`` and ``TrustServerCertificate=False`` in the database connection string.
trans-unit.target: To validate certificates with ADO.NET application code, set ``Encrypt=True`` and ``TrustServerCertificate=False`` in the database connection string.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Code sample: Retry logic for connecting to Azure SQL Database with ADO.NET](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee336243.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Code sample: Retry logic for connecting to Azure SQL Database with ADO.NET](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee336243.aspx).

trans-unit.source: SQL Server Management Studio also supports certificate validation.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server Management Studio also supports certificate validation.

trans-unit.source: In the **Connect to Server** dialog box, click **Encrypt connection** on the **Connection Properties** tab.
trans-unit.target: In the **Connect to Server** dialog box, click **Encrypt connection** on the **Connection Properties** tab.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] SQL Server Management Studio does not support connections to SQL Database in versions prior to SQL Server 2008 R2.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] SQL Server Management Studio does not support connections to SQL Database in versions prior to SQL Server 2008 R2.

trans-unit.source: Although SQLCMD supported SQL Database starting with SQL Server 2008, it does not support certificate validation in versions prior to SQL Server 2008 R2.
trans-unit.target: Although SQLCMD supported SQL Database starting with SQL Server 2008, it does not support certificate validation in versions prior to SQL Server 2008 R2.

trans-unit.source: To validate certificates with SQLCMD starting in SQL Server 2008 R2, use the ``-N`` command-line option and do not use the ``-C`` option.
trans-unit.target: To validate certificates with SQLCMD starting in SQL Server 2008 R2, use the ``-N`` command-line option and do not use the ``-C`` option.

trans-unit.source: By using the -N option, SQLCMD requests an encrypted connection.
trans-unit.target: By using the -N option, SQLCMD requests an encrypted connection.

trans-unit.source: By not using the ``-C`` option, SQLCMD does not implicitly trust the server certificate and is forced to validate the certificate.
trans-unit.target: By not using the ``-C`` option, SQLCMD does not implicitly trust the server certificate and is forced to validate the certificate.

trans-unit.source: For supplementary technical information, see [Azure SQL Database Connection Security](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/2951.windows-azure-sql-database-connection-security.aspx#comment-4847) article at the TechNet Wiki site.
trans-unit.target: For supplementary technical information, see [Azure SQL Database Connection Security](http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/2951.windows-azure-sql-database-connection-security.aspx#comment-4847) article at the TechNet Wiki site.

trans-unit.source: Authentication
trans-unit.target: Authentication

trans-unit.source: SQL Database supports only SQL Server authentication.
trans-unit.target: SQL Database supports only SQL Server authentication.

trans-unit.source: Windows authentication (integrated security) is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Windows authentication (integrated security) is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Users must provide credentials (login and password) every time they connect to SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Users must provide credentials (login and password) every time they connect to SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: For more information about SQL Server Authentication, see [Choosing an Authentication Mode](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms144284.aspx) in SQL Server Books Online.
trans-unit.target: For more information about SQL Server Authentication, see [Choosing an Authentication Mode](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms144284.aspx) in SQL Server Books Online.

trans-unit.source: [SQL Database V12](sql-database-v12-whats-new.md) allows users to authenticate at the database by using contained database users.
trans-unit.target: [SQL Database V12](sql-database-v12-whats-new.md) allows users to authenticate at the database by using contained database users.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Contained Database Users - Making Your Database Portable](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff929188.aspx), [CREATE USER (Transact-SQL)](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/ms173463.aspx), and [Contained Databases](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/ff929071.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Contained Database Users - Making Your Database Portable](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ff929188.aspx), [CREATE USER (Transact-SQL)](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/ms173463.aspx), and [Contained Databases](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/ff929071.aspx).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Microsoft recommends using contained database users to enhance scalability.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Microsoft recommends using contained database users to enhance scalability.

trans-unit.source: The Database Engine closes connections that remain idle for more than 30 minutes.
trans-unit.target: The Database Engine closes connections that remain idle for more than 30 minutes.

trans-unit.source: The connection must login again before it can be used.
trans-unit.target: The connection must login again before it can be used.

trans-unit.source: Continuously active connections to SQL Database require reauthorization (performed by the Database Engine) at least every 10 hours.
trans-unit.target: Continuously active connections to SQL Database require reauthorization (performed by the Database Engine) at least every 10 hours.

trans-unit.source: The Database Engine attempts reauthorization using the originally submitted password and no user input is required.
trans-unit.target: The Database Engine attempts reauthorization using the originally submitted password and no user input is required.

trans-unit.source: For performance reasons, when a password is reset in SQL Database, the connection will not be re-authenticated, even if the connection is reset due to connection pooling.
trans-unit.target: For performance reasons, when a password is reset in SQL Database, the connection will not be re-authenticated, even if the connection is reset due to connection pooling.

trans-unit.source: This is different from the behavior of on-premises SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: This is different from the behavior of on-premises SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: If the password has been changed since the connection was initially authorized, the connection must be terminated and a new connection made using the new password.
trans-unit.target: If the password has been changed since the connection was initially authorized, the connection must be terminated and a new connection made using the new password.

trans-unit.source: A user with the KILL DATABASE CONNECTION permission can explicitly terminate a connection to SQL Database by using the [KILL](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms173730.aspx) command.
trans-unit.target: A user with the KILL DATABASE CONNECTION permission can explicitly terminate a connection to SQL Database by using the [KILL](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms173730.aspx) command.

trans-unit.source: Logins and users
trans-unit.target: Logins and users

trans-unit.source: When managing logins and users in SQL Database, there are restrictions.
trans-unit.target: When managing logins and users in SQL Database, there are restrictions.

trans-unit.source: For the server-level principal login, the following restrictions apply:
trans-unit.target: For the server-level principal login, the following restrictions apply:

trans-unit.source: The database user in the master database corresponding to the server-level principal login cannot be altered or dropped.
trans-unit.target: The database user in the master database corresponding to the server-level principal login cannot be altered or dropped.

trans-unit.source: Although the server-level principal login is not a member of the two database roles **dbmanager** and **loginmanager** in the **master** database, it has all permissions granted to these two roles.
trans-unit.target: Although the server-level principal login is not a member of the two database roles **dbmanager** and **loginmanager** in the **master** database, it has all permissions granted to these two roles.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This login is created during server provisioning and is similar to the **sa** login in an instance of SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This login is created during server provisioning and is similar to the **sa** login in an instance of SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: For all logins, the following restrictions apply:
trans-unit.target: For all logins, the following restrictions apply:

trans-unit.source: US-English is the default language.
trans-unit.target: US-English is the default language.

trans-unit.source: To access the **master** database, every login must be mapped to a user account in the **master** database.
trans-unit.target: To access the **master** database, every login must be mapped to a user account in the **master** database.

trans-unit.source: The **master** database does not support contained database users.
trans-unit.target: The **master** database does not support contained database users.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify a database in the connection string, you will be connected to the **master** database by default.
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify a database in the connection string, you will be connected to the **master** database by default.

trans-unit.source: You must be connected to the **master** database when executing the ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP LOGIN`` and ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP DATABASE`` statements.
trans-unit.target: You must be connected to the **master** database when executing the ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP LOGIN`` and ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP DATABASE`` statements.

trans-unit.source: When executing the ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP LOGIN`` and ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP DATABASE`` statements in an ADO.NET application, using parameterized commands is not allowed.
trans-unit.target: When executing the ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP LOGIN`` and ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP DATABASE`` statements in an ADO.NET application, using parameterized commands is not allowed.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Commands and Parameters](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms254953.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Commands and Parameters](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms254953.aspx).

trans-unit.source: When executing the ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP DATABASE`` and ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP LOGIN`` statements, each of these statements must be the only statement in a Transact-SQL batch.
trans-unit.target: When executing the ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP DATABASE`` and ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP LOGIN`` statements, each of these statements must be the only statement in a Transact-SQL batch.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, an error occurs.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, an error occurs.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following Transact-SQL checks whether the database exists.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following Transact-SQL checks whether the database exists.

trans-unit.source: If it exists, a ``DROP DATABASE`` statement is called to remove the database.
trans-unit.target: If it exists, a ``DROP DATABASE`` statement is called to remove the database.

trans-unit.source: Because the ``DROP DATABASE`` statement is not the only statement in the batch, executing the following Transact-SQL statement will result in an error.
trans-unit.target: Because the ``DROP DATABASE`` statement is not the only statement in the batch, executing the following Transact-SQL statement will result in an error.

trans-unit.source: When executing the ``CREATE USER`` statement with the ``FOR/FROM LOGIN`` option, it must be the only statement in a Transact-SQL batch.
trans-unit.target: When executing the ``CREATE USER`` statement with the ``FOR/FROM LOGIN`` option, it must be the only statement in a Transact-SQL batch.

trans-unit.source: When executing the ``ALTER USER`` statement with the ``WITH LOGIN`` option, it must be the only statement in a Transact-SQL batch.
trans-unit.target: When executing the ``ALTER USER`` statement with the ``WITH LOGIN`` option, it must be the only statement in a Transact-SQL batch.

trans-unit.source: Only the server-level principal login and the members of the **dbmanager** database role in the **master** database have permission to execute the ``CREATE DATABASE`` and ``DROP DATABASE`` statements.
trans-unit.target: Only the server-level principal login and the members of the **dbmanager** database role in the **master** database have permission to execute the ``CREATE DATABASE`` and ``DROP DATABASE`` statements.

trans-unit.source: Only the server-level principal login and the members of the **loginmanager** database role in the **master** database have permission to execute the ``CREATE LOGIN``, ``ALTER LOGIN``, and ``DROP LOGIN`` statements.
trans-unit.target: Only the server-level principal login and the members of the **loginmanager** database role in the **master** database have permission to execute the ``CREATE LOGIN``, ``ALTER LOGIN``, and ``DROP LOGIN`` statements.

trans-unit.source: To ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP`` a user requires the ``ALTER ANY USER`` permission on the database.
trans-unit.target: To ``CREATE/ALTER/DROP`` a user requires the ``ALTER ANY USER`` permission on the database.

trans-unit.source: When the owner of a database role tries to add or remove another database user to or from that database role, the following error may occur: **User or role 'Name' does not exist in this database.** This error occurs because the user is not visible to the owner.
trans-unit.target: When the owner of a database role tries to add or remove another database user to or from that database role, the following error may occur: **User or role 'Name' does not exist in this database.** This error occurs because the user is not visible to the owner.

trans-unit.source: To resolve this issue, grant the role owner the ``VIEW DEFINITION`` permission on the user.
trans-unit.target: To resolve this issue, grant the role owner the ``VIEW DEFINITION`` permission on the user.

trans-unit.target: For more information about logins and users, see [Managing databases and logins in Azure SQL Database](sql-database-manage-logins.md).

trans-unit.source: Security best practices
trans-unit.target: Security best practices

trans-unit.source: Consider the following points to make your Azure SQL Database applications less vulnerable to security threats:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following points to make your Azure SQL Database applications less vulnerable to security threats:

trans-unit.source: Always use the latest updates: When connecting to your SQL Database, always use the most current version of tools and libraries to prevent security vulnerabilities.
trans-unit.target: Always use the latest updates: When connecting to your SQL Database, always use the most current version of tools and libraries to prevent security vulnerabilities.

trans-unit.source: For more information about which tools and libraries are supported, see [Azure SQL Database General Guidelines and Limitations](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee336245.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about which tools and libraries are supported, see [Azure SQL Database General Guidelines and Limitations](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee336245.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Block inbound connections on TCP port 1433: Only outbound connections on TCP port 1433 are needed for applications to communicate with SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Block inbound connections on TCP port 1433: Only outbound connections on TCP port 1433 are needed for applications to communicate with SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: If inbound communications are not needed by any other applications on that computer, ensure that your firewall continues to block inbound connections on TCP port 1433.
trans-unit.target: If inbound communications are not needed by any other applications on that computer, ensure that your firewall continues to block inbound connections on TCP port 1433.

trans-unit.source: Prevent injection vulnerabilities: To make sure that your applications do not have SQL injection vulnerabilities, use parameterized queries where possible.
trans-unit.target: Prevent injection vulnerabilities: To make sure that your applications do not have SQL injection vulnerabilities, use parameterized queries where possible.

trans-unit.source: Also, be sure to review code thoroughly and run a penetration test before deploying your application.
trans-unit.target: Also, be sure to review code thoroughly and run a penetration test before deploying your application.
